paragraphs.text: A few years ago, a CEO told me how she was struggling to get honest feedback from her board.
paragraphs.name: 515b

paragraphs.text: But “advice” is a much more welcoming word. Advice is about lending someone a hand. When someone gives you advice, they’re just looking out for you.
paragraphs.name: a0c0

paragraphs.text: The next time you’d like to get honest feedback, try asking for advice instead. Notice how much more people open up to you. See how swapping that one word makes a difference.
paragraphs.name: c93a
212e
paragraphs.text: The word “advice” unlocked all the honest feedback that CEO needed.
“What advice does anyone have for me?”
“What advice does anyone have for me?”
The word “advice” unlocked all the honest feedback that CEO needed.
paragraphs.name: 212e

virtuals.subtitle: Additionally, transformative- and authentic-styled leaders have much more success when it comes to receiving open, honest, and critical…

content.subtitle: Additionally, transformative- and authentic-styled leaders have much more success when it comes to receiving open, honest, and critical…

paragraphs.name: 267d
paragraphs.text: Claire Lew, great post! It’s typical of leaders to come across less opportunities for critical and honest feedback. The higher positioned the leader is, the less feedback they receive. Asking for “advice” rather than “feedback” can surely make a difference.

29ada8c3bbee.title: Thanks for sharing and so clearly describing this.

paragraphs.name: a59f
paragraphs.text: Thanks for sharing and so clearly describing this. I have found ‘Feedback’ almost always elicits a negative response, and ‘Advice’ elicits a helpful response even when it is critical.

a52f595301a2.title: ‘Advice’ insinuates giving ‘help’ whereas feedback almost insinuates ‘challenge’ – something that…

paragraphs.name: c230
paragraphs.text: ‘Advice’ insinuates giving ‘help’ whereas feedback almost insinuates ‘challenge’ – something that is far more scary to deliver! That’s a great bit of insight, thanks :)

paragraphs.name: ab22
paragraphs.text: Jysticejoy81gmail.com

virtuals.subtitle: I’m the type of person who asks for feedback on practically everything I do — I want to improve, and the only way I’m going to do that is…

e9a9083aec46.title: Such a simple, yet powerful change.

content.subtitle: I’m the type of person who asks for feedback on practically everything I do — I want to improve, and the only way I’m going to do that is…

paragraphs.name: ab2e
paragraphs.text: Such a simple, yet powerful change.

I’m the type of person who asks for feedback on practically everything I do — I want to improve, and the only way I’m going to do that is if people tell me what I need to improve on. I’ve found that asking for feedback gets the exact same response your CEO was having: silence. So I’m excited about using the word ‘advice’ next time.

e0451f917d34.title: How do you think teams can approach implementing “simple” changes like seeking feedback from the…

paragraphs.name: ab6b
paragraphs.text: How do you think teams can approach implementing “simple” changes like seeking feedback from the team? Do you think it has to be a top-down approach (e.g. form the CEO) or could it possible to implement change from the bottom-up?

virtuals.subtitle: Rephrasing certain words in a more light-tone can definitely have a positive impact on the way our listeners or readers respond to us.

f061734fdbe4.title: Great article and very well written, Claire!

content.subtitle: Rephrasing certain words in a more light-tone can definitely have a positive impact on the way our listeners or readers respond to us.

paragraphs.text: Great article and very well written, Claire!

paragraphs.name: 65ef
paragraphs.text: Rephrasing certain words in a more light-tone can definitely have a positive impact on the way our listeners or readers respond to us.
Thanks for sharing with us your insights!

a30b2f1fc897.title: Another good one is “Look, I need some help solving X, any ideas?”.

paragraphs.name: 29a2
paragraphs.text: Another good one is “Look, I need some help solving X, any ideas?”. Maybe not the best thing to say to your manager if you don’t have a great relationship already, but for unlocking your team’s feedback, it’s a ver powerful phrase. Whenever I ask the team for help on something, they bring a ton of solutions and ideas to the table without worrying that I will take them as criticism.

2de91dd64747.title: Nice post Claire, I have also found the word ‘candid’ has a similar unlocking power.

paragraphs.name: b525
paragraphs.text: Nice post Claire, I have also found the word ‘candid’ has a similar unlocking power.

virtuals.subtitle: However, in the case presented in the post, the word advice seems to be adequate since it stimulates participation. Especially, in the…

a6f5a576b535.title: To be honest, I avoid asking for advice most of the time.

content.subtitle: However, in the case presented in the post, the word advice seems to be adequate since it stimulates participation. Especially, in the…

paragraphs.name: 920f
paragraphs.text: To be honest, I avoid asking for advice most of the time. I do this because people love giving advice, even when it is not necessary. In addition, some advice is just to related to gossip and unimportant things.

paragraphs.name: f256
paragraphs.text: However, in the case presented in the post, the word advice seems to be adequate since it stimulates participation…

fddc510a4abc.title: Very interesting point of semantics, Claire.

paragraphs.text: Very interesting point of semantics, Claire. I never looked at the difference between “feedback” and “advice,” but you give a good example. Find the word that resonates, and you get a better response. Thanks for posting.

de3e313d740a.title: So going to try this at work!

paragraphs.name: cb3f
paragraphs.text: So going to try this at work!

paragraphs.name: 83f5
paragraphs.text: Nice insight: Claire Lee

c1e65085ba37.title: Thank you for this nice hack.

paragraphs.name: 87a2
paragraphs.text: Thank you for this nice hack. Here is one of mine: in my personal experience, I’ve found that using the term “perspective” instead of “opinion” makes it easier for a group to reach a consensus. “From my personal perspective,…” feels less dominant, less about ego and more about contributing to a collective reflexion than the usual “In my opinion”.

ae0d393f8932.title: Wow, that’s impressive that changing a couple words had such a drastic impact.

paragraphs.text: Wow, that’s impressive that changing a couple words had such a drastic impact. Thank you for sharing this, I have a feeling that this new way of asking will stick with me for many years to come.

paragraphs.name: d0d0
paragraphs.text: Great suggestion, love this! Rewording the same question can make such a difference. After explaining something and checking for understanding, instead of asking “Do you understand?” I’ll say “Does that make sense?” — It puts the responsibility on the speaker instead of the listener so they’re more likely to speak up if they’re uncertain.

3854a2f0cb9a.title: This hands down is the most efficient way to end every meeting/call going forward!

paragraphs.name: aca4
paragraphs.text: This hands down is the most efficient way to end every meeting/call going forward! Thank you for this….

e8e49d45b04f.title: So simple, so actionable I love this.

paragraphs.text: So simple, so actionable I love this. The word feedback does carry a lot of baggage and advice unlocks that for sure! Thank you for this great post!

f2a57e0dbb0.title: Something so simple that we always seek. This is great!

paragraphs.name: 1dbf
paragraphs.text: Something so simple that we always seek. This is great!

dc759afcc5a1.title: This is surely an effective way to ask for feedback.

paragraphs.name: 42bf
paragraphs.text: This is surely an effective way to ask for feedback. I experimented with ‘opinion’ and was pleasantly surprised by the willingness of the people to offer it.

virtuals.subtitle: This one little word makes all the difference…

dcaf3839e7ee.title: Unlock honest feedback with this one word

content.subtitle: This one little word makes all the difference…

paragraphs.text: Unlock honest feedback with this one word

paragraphs.name: a98a
paragraphs.text: This one little word makes all the difference…

d4f2799e53a3.title: This is so simple but effective :)

paragraphs.text: This is so simple but effective :)

bf560a77e549.title: Thanks for the practical and actionable advice!

paragraphs.name: a2fc
paragraphs.text: Thanks for the practical and actionable advice!

paragraphs.name: 06d3
paragraphs.text: Thanks, fantastic! It reminds me of the moment in which I heard for the first time the suggestion of substituting “but” with “and” when giving feedback (ehm… advice): from “I think it can work, but you’ll have to do XYZ” to “…it can work, AND if you do XYZ it will work even better”. It did miracles in my life whenever I remembered to apply it!

ad41460454ad.title: If we could ban “feedback,” that would be nice.

paragraphs.text: If we could ban “feedback,” that would be nice. It has a turn-off-ish air of clinical jargon about it. “Advice” is also two syllables, yet seems more open and welcoming. The bottom line: If it works, try it.
